statement: Selective SWS deprivation impairs declarative memory consolidation by 23-31% relative to control conditions.
evidence: Meta-analysis of 47 studies (N = 1,842 participants) with p < 0.001.

statement: REM sleep deprivation reduces procedural memory performance by 18-27% and impairs emotional memory discrimination.
evidence: Meta-analysis showing p < 0.01 and effect size d = 0.74 for emotional memory.

statement: Targeted memory reactivation during SWS using odor or auditory cues enhances declarative memory consolidation by 12-19%.
evidence: Comparison of cued versus uncued sleep conditions in TMR paradigm.

statement: The rigid separation between declarative-SWS and procedural-REM consolidation pathways appears oversimplified.
evidence: Recent studies show cross-stage interactions that modulate consolidation outcomes.

statement: Sleep spindle density during N2 sleep correlates positively with overnight memory improvement (r = 0.42).
evidence: Correlation analysis with p < 0.001 suggesting spindle-mediated consolidation beyond SWS.
